div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Cattle Plague. Cattle plague has broken out in the province of Minieh.
Prisons. The chief town of a mondirieh will hence- for h be provided with a central prison.
Quarantine.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague have been applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Moulmein.
New Court for Delingat.
A Summary Coart is to be established in the new Delingat Markaz, Behera Moudirieb, at the beginning of the year.
Native Penal Code.
A handy translation of the Penal Code of the Native Tribanals has been published by Diemer, Cairo. The price is P.T. 15.
Accession Dayfetes.
The second list of subscribers to the fonds for the celebration of the Khedive’s socession annivereary brings the total up to LB. 579.
The Pligrimage.
The Ministry of the Interior has issued a notice warning pilgrims who wish to accompany the Mahmal to Mecca to be at Suez by January 8 at latest.
Army Leoture,

The fifth Army lecture of the winter season will be delivered by Major Hardy, R.A.M.C., en ‘Water supplies and water purification,” at 6 p.m. on Tuesday evening, in the Model Room at Headquarters, Cairo.
Porte and Lighthouses Administration.

The offer of Messrs. Rob. Stabile and Co. has been accepted for the supply of coal to this administration at Alexandria, during the year 1907, at the price of P.T. 117 8/10 per Englith ton of 1,016 kilos.
Cerman Training Ship.

The Garman training ship Charlotte arrived at Alexdndria yesterday “from Smyrna, and exchanged salutes with Fort Saleh and H.M.S. Venus. This morning, the German Vice-Consul paid éo official visit to the commandant.
Publlo Health Dept.
MM. Samson Rabinovitch, Tewfik_Noury, Epaminondas D. Harissi, Abmed Abd-el-Salam, and Mohamed Abd-el Maguid, physicians, and
maciats, have been authorised to practise in
A Generous Loan.
M. George Zorvudachi has announced that
Orthodox Patriarchate at Jerasalem for the treasury of the Holy Sepulchre in order to cover the debt of that institution. He is only asking 2 per cent. ¢
Fatal Accident.

On Saturday afternoon a native porter attempted to pass between the boffers of two waggons at Gabbarystation with a sack of coal on his back. He was, however, run over, and received serious injaries, to which he succumbed shortly afterwards on the way to hospital.
Creek Fleet Lottery.

The following eleven numbers were announ- ced at the fourth drawing at Athens on the 15th ient. of the National Hellenic Fleet Lottery : 347,536; 864,453; 833,346; 519,013; 204 164; 891,382; 748,251; 400,853; 488,254; 734 290, 598,185. Farther particolare can be obtained from Mr. Daniel Fokas, Alexandria.
Egypt and Levant Steamship Company Limited.

We are informed that the accounts of the Egypt and Levant S:eamship Company Limited will be made up to 3ist December 1906 instead of the Ist. May 1907, thus making the first period of the company one of 8 months. We understand this is done so that the annual meetings of the company may be always held in the spring of the year.
An interesting Cenference.

The celebrated aeronaat Spelterini will give ‘a conference, illustrated by a series of views Yaken from a balloon at from 5,000 to 6,000 metres altitade, to-morrow night, at 9.30, in the Salle des Fétes ofthe New Khedivial Hotel. In view of the fame of this intrepid seronaut, who is so well known on the Continent, a large number of spectators may be expected.
New Theatre Tour Eiffel.

This theatre still maintains its position as a favourite haunt for those seeking amusement, and is nightly crowded. The programme, which is of the usual music-hall type, is an excellent one and contains several new names; notable among these are the Bight Otlesslys, who go through reveral evolutions and dances and secore a deal of applause. Miss Lizzie d’Avery, a Mexican Creole, also comes in for & good share of appreciation for her coon songs and dances. Mile. Bijou in an old favourite at this hoave, and the other artistes all acquit themselves well and help towards the success of the best show of the kind in town at present.
Notice for Tourists.
MOERIS HOTEL (ON LAKE KAROUN), Very comfortable. Good shooting. Patronised by Princess of Battenberg, Prince of Sweden, ete.
For particulare apply : A. TASOO, Proprietor, also proprietor of Crand Hotel Karoun, Fayoum.
GOVERNMENT POSTAGE.
NEW REGULATIONS.

Hitherto all the Ministries and Government Departments have been accustomed to send all their letters, parcele, etc., through the Egyp- tian Post Office free of charge. This system isto come to an end on February 1, 190%, when this class of postal matter, so far ae letters are concerned, will be put in the same position as ordinary public correspondence. The ‘fervice de |’Etat” stamp, which was affixed regardless of weight, will. be superseded by the ordinary stamps with sf overprint showing that the correspondence emanates from the Government. The letters will be charged according to weight. Parcels will be treated on the same footing as ordinary parcele, and the usual stamps will be employed with- out an overprint. In the case of money- orders commissions will be paid on the spot instead of allowirg accounts to run as heretofore. ‘
This new system is to be introduced for the purpose of protecting the Postal Administra- tion and should materially increase its receipts.
TESTIMONIAL TO DEAN BUTCHER.
LORD CROMER’S APPEAL.
The Earl of Cromer has sent to the “Times” the following appeal for the fand being raised to present a testimonial to Daan Butcher :

Sir,—At a meeting held at the “British Agency on November 28 it was decided to invite subscriptions with a view to presenting a testimonial to the Very Rev. Dean- Batcher, who is about to leave. Egypt after having held the post of chaplain of All Saints’ Church, Cairo, for a period of 26 years.
[ shall feel greatly obliged if yon will allow mé, thfough your colamn», to bring the matter to the notice of the numerons friends of Dean Butcher who are no longer resident in Egypt.
Subscriptions may be sent to the manager of the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo.
I am, Sir, very faithfully yours,
Cairo, Nov. 30. Cromer,
THE MAHMAL.

The last ceremony in connexion with the Mahmal will take place on Monday, the 31st inst., when» all Government offices will be closed. On the 3rd January, the escort of the Mehmal will leave Abbassieh for Suez, en route for the Heejaz. .
Ahmed Effendi Atif has been attached the Mahmal as physician.
KASR EL AINI.
. Saad Pasha Zaghloul, Minister of Education, visited the Kasr-el-Aini Medical School yester- day morning.

The commission of British physicians who sre coming from England to examine the Kasr el-Aini students of the 1st and Qnd years are expected to arrive in Cairo to-morrow. The examination will be héld on the 23rd inst. and the results published on the 28th.
PORT SAID MOTOR CO.

To the order of the Port Said Motor Com- pany, Messra. Dongill and Co., Ld. of Leeds, have built a 22-seated motor char-A bano, which was put through its trials in England recently preparatory to being employed on the Port Said to Cairo route, a distance of about 190 miles ot level sandy country. The cars are of the friction-driven type, and are built to meet the requirements cf the Port S1id Company, who ask for cara of simple and reliable dzserip- tion as mechanics are none too numerous in Egypt. The vehicle already tested is gear- less, and has an engine giving 20 h.p. at 800 revolutions per minute, accelerating to 30 b.p. at 1,200 revolutions, The flywheel is cast with a smooth sarface, and the car is fitted with two direct-driven friction wheels ranning on a shaft. By shifting the diso of one of these two wheels across the face of the flywheel, the car can be moved in either direction, backward or forward. By these means also itis possible to obtain any gra- dation in speed, and the car whan deacanding a hill canbe pulled up with perfect ease by moving one of the leather-facad discs across the reverse side of the flywheel diso.To obviate avy difficulty that might be experienced in running the car over the sandy tracts of Egypt the back wheels have been fitted with broad and flat twin tyres. The ran fally bore out all that Messrs. Dongill claim forthe car. A distance of thirty miles was covered at an average of sixteen or seventeen miles an hour, thoagh the engines were not pat toa trial of their fall capacity through fear of the law.
— es

DOW COVINGTON’S WORK.

Mr. Dow Covington has been authorised by the Antiquities Service to clear the casing stones W. of those excavated by him in 1902 and depicted by Professor Breasted in his new history of Ancient Egypt published this year. These stones are believed to form the northern, base line of the Great Pyramid. The excava- tion is one of extreme interest, as it will show whether any more of these superb stones exist west of those above referred to.
Thie is one vf several excavations on which Mr. Covington is working at the Great Pyramid, on “the conclusion of which full particulars will be given to our readers.
SALE OF YACHT.

We are requested by Prince Atiz Pasha Hassan to contradict the report published by several of our Cairo contemporaries of the sale of his steam yacht Cuhona to the Coast Goard Administration, and to state that his Highness has no intention of disposing of the vessel.

A correspondent writes :—A Cairo morning. newspaper, in its issue of Satarday last, made some extraordinarily nonsensical ‘statements about the Cahona. It described her as of “700 tonnage register,” whatever that may mean. The fact is that the yacht is only 193 tons nett register, 854 tons gross, and 498 tons Thames measurement, The same paper says that she is 900 horse power..-The vessel is only an auxiliary screw craft of 79 horse power: The statement that she can develop a apeed of 19 knots is incredible. The Cahona was built in 1882.
_-- SALE OF PALAOK.

Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel has sold his palucé at Ghizeh to Youssef Bey Monssiri, of Cairo, for L.E. 400,000, including brokerage. The price will be paid in four equal instal- ments, the firat on delivery of the property this month, the second in December, 1907, the third in Jaly, and the fourth in December, 1908.
The palace, which covers ait, area of 189,000 square metres, is sitaated near the Ghizeb Zoological Gardens, .
It is said that a Cairo land company has already offered Monssiri Bey L.E 440,000 for his new property, but the offer has been refused. ‘ ”
LAND AT RAMLEH.

An 6ffsr has been made for the estate of Mr. Constantine Meimarachi near Bulkeley Station, known as the “Suocession Pangalaki.” It is about 40,000 pica in extent, and P.T. 100 has been offered by a land company at Cairo. The offer has been refused since the land is sure to rise in value owing to its excellent situation and to the forthcoming construction of the Corniche route.

' KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE. The Khedivial Mail 8.8. and Graving Dock Company, Ltd., have purchased the fiae 8.8. Ifata,; which will leave England on Wednesdsy next, the 19th inst. direct for Alexandria, We wou!d draw the attention of our readers to the notice appeating in another colomn of to-day's issne relative to the increase of the company’s capital. eee
POST OFFICE RIFLES AND THE EGYPTIAN CAMPAIGN.

In presenting the challenge cup and prises won this year by the Post Office Rifles (24th Middlesex V.R C.) last week, General the Hon. Bir N.G. Lyttelton expressed the interest he had felt in the regiment since 1878, and particularly mentioned having been brought into contact with the detachment of two officers and 44 men from the Post Office Rifles doring the Ezyptian campaign which ended with the battle of Tel-el-Kebir. He believed that that was the first time our Volunteer force was represented on foreign service.

HASHISH SMUGGLING.

The Cosstguards confiscated 134 kilos of hashish on the Khedivial Mail Line’s quay on Friday night. The drag was found iu small pieces wrapped in thio silver paper and concealed be- tween the stitches of a cotton mattress which an Italian barbar reseived per the 8.8. Osma- nieh. The latter, on being questioned, stated that he had been requested to receive delivery of the mattress for a friend of his, who was expected at Alexandria shortly from Greece, and that he did so, being unaware of the presence of hashish.

div.head: SITUATION IN GERMANY.
div.p: APPEAL TO PATRIOTISM.
THE REICHSTAG ELECTIONS.
Berlin , December, 15.

The newspapers comment very freely on the internal situation. They say that the Govern- ment has energetically taken upon itself to rid itself, with a strong hand, of the influences exercised by the Clericals, who only by avarice and pusillanimity refused to vote the necessary funds,
The Government is appealing to public opi- nion considering. that the people will be more generous than the Clerical and Socialist majority in the Reichstag.

The Liberal and Conservative papers approve the firm and national attitude of the Govern- ment and regard the dissolution of the Reichs- tag as s deliverance from the intolerable influence of the Clerical party.
On the occasion of the dissolution the Chan- cellor received innumerable congratulations
from all parts of Germany. ( Reuter)
Berlin, December 15. The elections for the Reichstag will take Place on 26th January. (Reuter)
Berlin, December 15. The elections for the Reichstag have been fixed for the 25th January. (Havas)
Berlin, December 16.

The National Liberals and Radicals have issued respective manifestoes. The former denounce the Centrists and Socialists and appeal warmly to German patriotism to bring the war in Damaraland to a successful finish. The Radicals avoid the Colonial issue and demand less bureaucratic government and more political freedom. ( Reuter)

div.head: FUTURE OF TRANSVAAL.
div.p: LORD MILNER ON SITUATION.
London, December 15. Lord Milner, speaking at Manchester, said Heaven alone knew what the end would be in
the Transvaal Colony in view of the granting if
of self-government. The sole hope was that the very desperateness of the situation and the
threatened economic catastrophe, might cause |
the Transvaalers to sink their differences and effect a temporary arrangement, which, if backed by a strong body of Colonial opinion, the Imperial Government might hesitate to reject, (Reuter)

Johannesburg, December 15. The Constitution has provoked varying comments in the Transvaal, but the general feeling seems to be that it will be worked by all parties in such a way as to exclude the possibility of real injury to the gold industry, (Reuter)

div.head: CONGO FREE STATE.
div.p: BELGIUM AND ANNEXATION. Brussels, December 15. Parliament concluded the debate on the Congo and adopted a resolution of confidence in the Government requesting the committee to report immediately on the question of annexation. (Reuter)

div.head: Menelik'S SUCCESSOR CHOSEN.
div.p: A SATISFACTORY TREATY.

Addis Abeba, December 15. Menelik has chosen as-his successor his eldest daughter's son, aged 15. General satis- faction is expressed in diplomatic circles at the signature of a treaty precluding the possibility of dispute with the Powers upon Menelik’s demise, and «settling satisfactorily the long- standing railway question, The agreement is regarded as strengthening the relations be- tween Great Britain, - France, and Italy. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN BOMB OUTRAGE.
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 15. A bomb was thrown at Admiral Dubassow, ex-Governor-General of Moscow, whilst driving in a fashionable street here today. He was slightly wounded. Two of the perpetrators of the outrage have been arrested. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH BUDGET.
div.p: Paris, December 16.
The Chamber of Deputies has approved the whole of the Budget.(Havas)

div.head: FIRST GERMAN SUBMARINE.
div.p: Berlin, December 15. The first German submarine was commis- sioned at Kiel yesterday. (Reuter)

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONVENTION.
div.p: Madrid, December 16. The Chamber has ratified the Algeciras Convention. (Havas)

div.head: FRENCH CHURCH WAR.
div.p: SENSATIONAL DISCOVERIES.
YESTERDAY'S SERVICES.
Paris, December 15.

Several bishops and many seminarists have already been expelled from their residences, amid slight disturbances. The people in Lyons knelt in the streets to receive the blessing of the Archbishop on leaving the Palace. Gendar- mes at Arras were compelled to force the entrance to the seminary, which was barricad- ed with trees, thorns, and mattresses. (Reuter)
Paris, December 15.

The newspapers, declare that Monsignor Montagnini’s papers, which have been seized by the police, show that he intrigued with French politicians and advised wealthy Catho- lics to cause a fall on the Bourse in order to influence public opinion. Other sensational disclosures, they say, are also made. (Reuter)
Paris, December 16.

The Government interferes as little as possible with the services in the churches, believing that the priests, while owing obedience to the Vatican, disapprove of the Pope's policy. 15 episcopal palaces and 28 seminaries were closed yesterday.

There was no disturbance of the services in the churches here this morning, but tumults occurred in several provincial towns, where cheering crowds escorted bishops to the cathedrals and to their palaces. (Reuter)
Paris, December 15,
M. Briand introduced a Bill in the Chamber securing the service of the cult according to the law of 1901. (Havas)

div.head: THE SHAH.
div.p: CONDITION UNCHANGED. Teheran, December 16.
The Shah’s condition is unchanged. The heir apparent has arrived here and was warmly welcomed by the Sheh’s brother, Naib Salta- neh, They drove to the Palace together,
( Reuter)

div.head: DISTURBANCES IN STAMBOUL.
div.p: CLAMOURING FOR WAGES.
CONSTANTINOPLE, December 16,

Serious disturbances have taken place here. 200 time-expired sailors and marines made a demonstration demanding their discharge and payment of the arrears of the wages due to them. The naval officers who intervened were greeted with showers of stones and injured. Finally, an aide-de-camp from the Sultan promised that their demands would be granted, and the men thereupon dispersed. (Reuter)

div.head: KING HAAKON IN BERLIN.
div.p: Berlin, December 15,
The’ Emperor and Empress received the King and Queen of Norway at the station. They then drove in procession to the Palace at Potsdam. (Reuter)
Potsdam, December 15.
The Norwegian Sovereigns have arrived. At the banquet friendly, toasts were exchanged. (Havas)

div.head: LOND ON’S LONGEST “TUBE.”
div.p: FINSBURY TO HAMMERSMITH.
London, December 16.

Mr. Lloyd George yesterday opened Lon- don’s longest tube, which runs from Finsbury to Hammersmith, via Piccadilly, forming the backbone of the electrical system which the Charing Cross and Hampstead line will com- plete in June. (Reuter )

div.head: THE DREADNOUGHT DAMAGED.
div.p: London, December 16. The Dreadnought has been examined in dry dock, and it was discovered to be necessary to replace two plates. It is believed she struck some sunken wreckage during her recent fur- ther trials. (Reuter)

div.head: SEARCH FOR HELIOPOLIS.
div.p: Brussels, December 16.
The Government is sending M. Capart to discover the site of Heliopolis. He will leave in February. (Havas)

div.head: ANOTHER SPRINGBOK SUCCESS.
div.p: London, December 15.
Football. Rugby. The South Africans de- feated Cumberland by 21 points to nil.( Reuter)

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandria. FIRST-CLASS HOTEL. Lately Built and Furnished. TERMS P.T. 5O PER DAY. Special terms to Government Officials.

div.head: WEEK AFTER WEEK IN EGYPT.
div.p: (Mr. Edward Dicey in the “Daily TELEGRAPH”).
(Continued.) Cairo, December 1.

I arrived in Cairo too late to attend the meeting held last Thursday, under the pre- sidency of Lord Cromer and the American Consul-General, with the view of raising a testimonial to Dean Butcher, who for the last quarter of a century has held the chaplaincy of All Saints’ Church at Cairo. I have been asked to call attention to the proposed sub- scription list, and in as far as goodwill is con- cerned would gladly do anything in my power to favour so good an object. I could wish, however, that the request had been addressed to someone more competent to deal with Church matters than I am myself. Ever so many years ago the then so called Tractarian Bishop of Exeter, Dr. Philpotts, bad an embittered newspaper controversy with he then Sir Culling Eardley, a leading member of the Low Church party, about the use of vestments, or something of that sort. In the course of this controversy the Bishop ex- pressed an opinion that the baronet had no right, holding the views be did, to call himself a member of the Church of England. The baronet retorted by saying that he had always remained «within the fold of the Church, and to substantiate his case added that he was almost an occasional communicant. recall this definition, which somehow bas remained in my memory, to the exclusion, I fear, of many things far better worth re- membering, because it describes more correctly than any other form of words my attitude towards All Saints Church, Cairo. I have beer for years "almost an occasional member” of Dean Batcher’s congregation. That is all I can fairly say. I would therefore speak of him-rather as a man of the world than as a church goer. I can speak from long personal acquaintance, and I trust I may say friendship —of the dignity with which he maintained his position, of his invariable kindness to the sick and poor and suffering, of his great tolerance for those who did not share his own religious views, of his sweetness of temper, of his charm of manner to all sorts and conditions of men, of his modesty in his own estimate of his literary ability, and of the zeal and energy with which be discharged the duties of an arduous and,! fear, often a thankless office.

I have often thought to myself, while listen- ing to the small, kindly jokes, quaint com- pounds of simplicity and shrewdness, while gazing at his never failing smile, studying the good sense and love of manhood in general, and of his flock individually, which formed the never-failing basis of all his utterances, while casting my eyes on a scrupulously neat figure, which even in rusty clothes bore unmistakably the impress of a gentleman born and bred, that it 1 had been asked by any of my painter friends to name a model for the Vicar of Wake- field | should have recommended them without hesitation to come to Cairo and take Dean Butcher as their model.

He was fond of society, and in 1881,when I first met the Dean in Cairo, the European com- munity in general, and the British community in particular, was far smaller than it is to-day. With the exception of the British officials and the officers of the British garrison, we all had our house of call at Shepheard’s. We were not then divided into sets and cliques. Our life and our amusements were simpler. Balls and con- certs were events of very rare occurrence. Golf and lawn tennis and polo were hardly know. We had no race course, and we spent the time chiefly in picnic parties to the sights of Cairo. and the evenings at the houses of some few of the permanent residents, who had reception nights, at which all their acquaintances were asked to attend, without any special invitation. At these parties the Dean was-a frequent and always welcome guest, Year after after the Cairo society grew more artificial, and I suspect the Dean felt, as many of our contemporaries did, some: what out of his element in new social or under which the one object of the leaders of fashion seems to be to render the Cairo season the exact counterpart, on a smaller scale, of the London season. To return, however, to my subject. I which most heartily that some of my reader, who have attended the services-at All Saints’ Church during their frequent visits to Cairo, and who have enjoyed the advantages of listening to his sermons, and of bearing the services of the Church of England performed in a manner worthy of the beauty of one Liturgy, would consider whether they do not owe some further recognition of the aged pastor who for twenty-six years has upheld the welfare of our Church in Cairo, and who is now about to ley down his post, well strick- en in years, and, I fear, not overburdened with means during his remaining years. Life is somehow expensive in Cairo, and oar British officials are not in a position to save much out of their incomes. If anything can be done to assist the retiring chaplain, it is to the British visitors we mart lock for help. All I can say is that any help given will be bestowed on a good servant of the Church of England, and on one who has dove good work far all those to whom the honour and the dignity of our National Church are justly dear.

Intestate estates and rival olsiman is under wills capable of various interpretations have furnished matter for litigation and scandal ever since our remote forbears had property to leave behind, and the desire to dictate -how and by whom their property w:s to be adminis- tered after they were dead and buried. A dis- puted will is bad enough in the West, but in the East it is the very devil and all. About two month ago Prince Mohamed Ibrabim, still a very young man, was-killed by a motor accident in France, leaving a youthful] widow, three or four

little children, and a fortune popularly esti. mated at £5,000,000. After all, as Sam Slick said, there is a great deal of human nature about man—and I should add, myself, a good deal more, about woman, It will not, there fore, surprise anyone to learn that any number of the poor young Princess's relatives by birth or by marriage considered themselves far better qualified than she could be to manage her affairs for her and her children, and to spend her money wisely, prudently, and profitably The Mohamedan courts have even greater powers of protracting proceedings than our own tribunals, and owing to the elaborate rales laid down in the Koran for the protection of concubines, eunuchs, servants, and slaves, who have all legal claims against the estate in the event of its liquidation, years might have easily gone by in needless litigation before the heirs of the deceased Prince could have ascer- tained what ‘amount accrued to them as his residuary legatees. All kinds of scandal are current as to family intrigues, whose object was to secure the administration of the estate for the advantage of their authors. As these rumors are based upon hearsay reports, it is impossible to test their accuracy. All one can fairly state is that at the widow's own request, her late husband's friend, Me Carton de Wiart, the leading. Anglo-Belgian advocate in Egypt interested himself on her behalf, and with the active support of Lord Cromer, carried through an arrangement, under . which the -Princes® mill retain the control of her estate, subject to the advice and, approval of trustees in when both she and the Egyptian public have fall and well-deserved. confidence. All’s well that. ends well, and to my mind the most interesting part of this curious incident consists in the light it throws upon the utter discrepancy. between the ladies of the barem.as depicted in M. Pierre Loti’s "Les Desinhéritées” and the ladies of the harem in the real work-a-day world. In common with other Turkish; ladies of rank and fortune, the Princess, when in Europe, discarded the yashmak, and showed herself at theatres and watering-places dressed after the fashions of Europe ; bat when at home she displayed no desire to retain her newly- acquired freedom of to change the mode of life in the harem which has been adopted by her predecessors for generation after generation, and will be pursued by her successors for gene- rations to come. M. Loti is a charming writer and his descriptions of the external life of Stamboul are beyond praise, but as the cham- pion of harem reform he describe an imaginary world occupied by creations of his own prolific fancy.

div.head: THE HOUSE OF ISLAM
div.p: As a fascinating and faithful portrayer of Oriental life and character Mr. Marmeduke Pickthall gained the respect of the reading public when he wrote “Said the Fisherman.” With his latest work be loses none of the reputation then gained. Rather, we are the more convinced that his gifts are peculiarly adapted to dealing with Eastern subjects, and he is, therefore, well advised to return to them. His knowledge of provincial Turkey is not that of the tourist. He is the fond student, who delights in describing the interesting if some what erratic characteristics of these people he knows so well. “The House of Islam” is a simple story, entirely without semblace of plot, yet it compels interest. The seductive glamour of the East runs through it, and while reading it one lives for the time being in the quaint scenes’ and surroundings therein depicted The chief characters brought to our notice are two Syrian brothers, who at the time we make their acquaintance are living in Constantinople. They form one of those striking contrasts of character not infrequently met with in families. Shams-ud-din is a well to-do shopkeeper, beloved by his neighbors for his saintly fife, and honored for his great erodi tion. Milhem, on the other hand, is a “man of the world,” ambitious, heartless, and devoid of sentiment. Milhem obtains a commission to undertake the settlement of a band of Circassians in a distant and wild hill-district of Syria. In order to enable him to carry out the commission, he is compelled to seek funds from his brother, his own money having been expended in a long struggle to gain official recognition. Shems-ud-din gives him unstint- ing aid, but Milhem’s gratitude speedily vanishes when Shems-ud-din expresses his determination to accompany him on -his journey. For many reasons the presence of his simple and pious brother with the party was undesirable, but his efforts to dissuade him are futile. They travel together, and Milhem, now that he is no longer in need of assistance is not slow to show his disinclination to spend any more time in the company of Shems-ud-din than is absolutely necessary When the commis- sion has been executed, Milhem returns to the capital, but Shems-ud-din elects. to settle in the hill-town, and marries. Years go by, and with them bring trouble for the saintly shop keeper. His son in early youth leaves the paternal roof, and, later, is introduced to the whirlpool of official life by his anole. The daughter, the darling of the father's heart, i: taken, with consumption.

Recovery is believed to be hopeless, but the old man, instead of resigning himself to the will of Allah, takes her to the distant town of El Guds, and places her in charge of an “infidel” Frankish doctor. Shems-ud-din,

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
